case_data.name: Przybocki v. United States Department of Agriculture
case_data.plaintiff_description: A business owner and customer seeking to disseminate and receive, respectively, information about easily-digestible food products.
case_data.summary:
This is a case about the free speech implications of government restrictions on the labels of various packaged foods. On March 28, 2023, a business owner, his business, and a customer of his business sued the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA), its Food Safety and Inspection Service (FSIS) and the Food and Drug Administration (FDA)  in the U.S. District Court for the District of Nevada. Represented by local counsel as well as the Institute for Justice, the Plaintiffs sued for violations of the First Amendment and sought declaratory relief, an injunction lifting the ban on their desired labeling, attorneys fees, and any other legal or equitable relief the court deemed fair. The case was assigned to Judge Anne R. Traum and Magistrate Judge Daniel J. Albregts. 

            The business owner and his company allege that FSIS required them to remove terms such as “low-FODMAP” (an acronym for items low in various difficult-to-digest sugars), “deliciously digestible,” and “gut loving” from their product labels. They further allege that the removal violated their First Amendment rights because the statements, while allegedly verifiable and non-misleading, were ultimately impermissible. FSIS and FDA permit claims such as these only if they are defined in their regulations and included on a pre-approved list of similar nutrient content claims (for example, the agencies maintain established standards for what counts as “low sodium,” but not what count as “low-FODMAP”). Consequently, plaintiffs allege that this “pre-approved and exclusive” list of statements violates the First Amendment because it excludes otherwise true and verifiable information that consumers, such as the consumer-plaintiff in this case, might want to know. 

On June 23, 2023, defendants filed a motion to dismiss, which the plaintiffs responded to on August 18, 2023. The case is ongoing.
case_data.summary_short: On March 28, 2023, a customer and a small business owner filed suit against the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) and the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA), alleging a policy preventing businesses from truthfully labeling their food products violated the First Amendment. The plaintiffs alleged the agencies' decision to strike desired phrases from their food product labels  โ phrases which they claim were verifiable and non-misleading โ  violated the FIrst Amendment. As of January 3, 2024, the case is ongoing.

AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 
22
vs. 
23
UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF 
24
AGRICULTURE;  
25 THOMAS J. VILSACK, in his official capacity 
as Secretary of Agriculture;  
26
UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF 
AGRICULTURE FOOD SAFETY AND 
27
INSPECTION SERVICE;  
28

Case 2:23-cv-00455-ART-DJA   Document 1   Filed 03/28/23   Page 2 of 32
 
1 SANDRA ESKIN, in her official capacity as 
United States Deputy Under Secretary for Food 
2
Safety;  
UNITED STATES FOOD AND DRUG 
3
ADMINISTRATION; and  
4 ROBERT CALIFF, in his official capacity as 
Commissioner of the United States Food and 
5
Drug Administration, 
 
6
Defendants. 
7
 
Plaintiffs  Michelle  Przybocki,  Ketan  Vakil,  and  Gourmend  Foods,  LLC  file  this 
8
9 Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief and sue the United States Department of 
10
Agriculture (the โUSDAโ); Thomas J. Vilsack, in his official capacity as United States Secretary 
11
of Agriculture; the United States Department of Agriculture Food Safety and Inspection Service 
12
(โFSISโ); Sandra Eskin, in her official capacity as United States Deputy Under Secretary for Food 
13
Safety; the United States Food and Drug Administration (the โFDAโ); and Robert Califf, in his 
14
15 official capacity as Commissioner of the United States Food and Drug Administration, as follows: 
16
INTRODUCTION 
17
1.  This is a First Amendment challenge on behalf of Michelle Przybocki, a consumer 
18
desiring factual information about the ingredients in foods, and Ketan Vikal, who, through his 
19
small  business  Gourmend  Foods,  LLC  (โGourmendโ),  wants  to  convey  this  same  factual 
20
21 information to Michelle and others like her. That information is about difficult-to-digest sugars 
22
known  as  FODMAPs  (an  acronym  for  fermentable  oligosaccharides,  disaccharides, 
23
monosaccharides  and  polyols).  Gourmendโs  food  products  are  factually,  verifiably  low-
24
FODMAP, and Ketan and Gourmend want to convey this truthful information on the Gourmend 
25
labels.  Michelle,  who  is  extremely  sensitive  to  FODMAPs,  wants  to  see  these  facts  on 
26
27 Gourmendโs and many other businessesโ food labels so that she can improve her quality of life 
28
2 

Case 2:23-cv-00455-ART-DJA   Document 1   Filed 03/28/23   Page 3 of 32
 
1 by more easily identifying the foods that will not upset her digestion and aggravate her medical 
2
condition.  
3
2.  But the federal government categorically bans this truthful speech. Worse, this ban 
4
(the  โBanโ)  is  not  because  of  any  contention  that  the  information  is  inaccurate,  false,  or 
5
misleading in any wayโGourmendโs products are verifiably low-FODMAP, and the Agencies 
6
7 have not claimed otherwise. Rather, the USDA, FSIS, and the FDA (collectively, the โAgenciesโ) 
8
Ban the use of the words โlow-FODMAPโ and related factual statements on food labels simply 
9
because they are not on the Agenciesโ outdated list of pre-approved nutrient content information 
10
that can be provided on food labels. Moreover, even attempting to change the federal regulations 
11
to add new information to the preapproved list takes years and far more resources than most 
12
13 people possess. 
14
3.  This lawsuit seeks to vindicate the First Amendment free speech rights of Ketan 
15
and Gourmend to tell the truth on food labels and Michelleโs First Amendment right to receive 
16
that truthful information that businesses like Gourmend would voluntarily choose to provide but 
17
for the Ban. Put simply, the First Amendment does not allow the government to decide which 
18
19 facts consumers are allowed to learn.  
20
THE PARTIES 
21
4.  Plaintiff Michelle Przybocki (pronounced Prizz-bahki) is a citizen and resident of 
22
this district and was residing in this district during all the events at issue in this lawsuit. 
23
5.  Plaintiff Ketan Vakil (pronounced Vah-keel) is a citizen and resident of New York 
24
25 City, New York. Through his business, Gourmend Foods, LLC, Ketan does business in this 
26
district. 
27
28
3 

Case 2:23-cv-00455-ART-DJA   Document 1   Filed 03/28/23   Page 4 of 32
 
1 6.  Gourmend Foods, LLC (โGourmendโ) is a New York limited liability company in 
2
good standing and doing business in this district. 
3
7.  Ketan is Gourmendโs managing member and sole member. 
4
8.  Defendant the United States Department of Agriculture (the โUSDAโ) is a federal 
5
agency charged with regulating food labeling and enforcing regulations on food labels, among 
6
7 other things.  
8
9.   Defendant Thomas J. Vilsack is the United States Secretary of Agriculture. 
9
Secretary  Vilsack  has  direct  authority  over  the  United  States  Department  of  Agricultureโs 
10
personnel and is charged with the responsibility of enforcing the related laws, regulations, and 
11
policies of the United States. He is being sued only in his official capacity.  
12
13 10.  Defendant  the  United  States  Department  of  Agriculture  Food  Safety  and 
14
Inspection Service (โFSISโ) is a federal agency that is part of the United States Department of 
15
Agriculture and is charged with regulating food labeling.  
16
11.   Defendant Sandra Eskin is the United States Deputy Under Secretary for Food 
17
Safety. Deputy Under Secretary Eskin has direct authority over the United States Department of 
18
19 Agriculture Food Safety and Inspection Serviceโs personnel and is charged with the responsibility 
20
of enforcing the related laws, regulations, and policies of the United States. She is being sued 
21
only in her official capacity.  
22
12.  Defendant the United States Food and Drug Administration (the โFDAโ) is a 
23
federal agency charged with regulating food labeling. It is part of the United States Department 
24
25 of Health and Human Services.  
26
13.  Defendant Robert Califf is Commissioner of the United States Food and Drug 
27
Administration. Commissioner Califf has direct authority over the United States Food and Drug 
28
4 

Case 2:23-cv-00455-ART-DJA   Document 1   Filed 03/28/23   Page 5 of 32
 
1 Administrationโs personnel and is charged with the responsibility of enforcing the related laws, 
2
regulations, and policies of the United States. He is being sued only in his official capacity.  
3
JURISDICTION AND VENUE 
4
14.  Plaintiffs bring this civil rights lawsuit pursuant to the United States Constitution 
5
and the Declaratory Judgment Act (28 U.S.C. ยง 2201) for violations of the First Amendment to 
6
7 the United States Constitution.   
8
15.  Plaintiffs seek a declaration that the Ban on the use of โLow FODMAPโ and 
9
related truthful statements on food labels violates the First Amendment, as well as both temporary 
10
injunctive relief and permanent injunctive relief against enforcement of the Ban. 
11
16.  This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to 28 U.S.C. 
12
13 ยงยง 1331 (federal question jurisdiction) and 1343(a)(3) (civil rights jurisdiction).  
14
17.  Venue lies in this Court pursuant to 28 U.S.C. ยง 1391(b)(2) and (c)(1). Lead 
15
Plaintiff Michelle Przybocki resides in this District and has done so since 1976. As a result, most 
16
of the witnesses for this case are located in this district. Additionally, Plaintiffs Ketan Vakil and 
17
Gourmend Foods, LLC, do business in this district, and the Defendants all operate in this district 
18
19 as well. 
20
FACTUAL ALLEGATIONS 
21
A.  Michelle Przybocki needs to be able to easily identify low-FODMAP foods.  
22
18.  Plaintiff Michelle Przybocki is a speech therapist living and working in Las Vegas, 
23
Nevada.  
24
25 19.  In 2019, Michelle became very ill and nearly died of digestive complications. 
26
After that, whenever Michelle ate, she would often experience debilitating pain. 
27
28
5 

Case 2:23-cv-00455-ART-DJA   Document 1   Filed 03/28/23   Page 6 of 32
 
1 20.  Michelle learned that she had a severe case of irritable bowel syndrome (โIBSโ) 
2
and that if she wanted to reduce the pain to a manageable level, she should follow a low-FODMAP 
3
diet.  
4
21.  โFODMAPโ  is  an  acronym  that  stands  for  โfermentable  oligosaccharides, 
5
disaccharides, monosaccharides, and polyols.โ  
6
7 22.  FODMAPs are certain carbohydrates, or sugars, that can cause intestinal distress.  
8
23.  FODMAPs can be found in certain foods and ingredients that are commonly used 
9
to impart flavor, such as onions and garlic.  
10
24.  FODMAPs are well-known in the mainstream scientific and medical communities. 
11
25.  IBS is a digestive disorder that affects 10-15% of the American population. The 
12
13 population of the United States is over 330 million people. That means 33 to 50 million Americans 
14
potentially suffer from IBS.  
15
26.  IBS is not the only digestive disorder that impacts the lives of a substantial number 
16
of Americans. 
17
27.  Michelleโs IBS symptoms made daily living a struggle. Often, after Michelle ate, 
18
19 she would suffer from extreme pain that would immobilize her for many hours.  
20
28.  Michelleโs symptoms kept her confined to her home for extended periods of time. 
21
29.  Michelleโs experience is not unique. 
22
30.  A low-FODMAP diet is commonly recommended by doctors to people who suffer 
23
from IBS and other intestinal issues. 
24
25 31.  Studies have shown that most patients report significant improvement of their IBS 
26
symptoms when they eliminate FODMAPs from their diet.  
27
28
6 

Case 2:23-cv-00455-ART-DJA   Document 1   Filed 03/28/23   Page 7 of 32
 
1 32.  For many people, following a low-FODMAP diet is the key to avoiding pain and 
2
to living a normal life.  
3
33.  For these reasons, Michelle decided to follow a low-FODMAP diet.  
4
34.  Michelle needed to find low-FODMAP foods to have any chance of living a 
5
somewhat-normal life.  
6
7 35.  Michelle  spent  countless  hours  searching  for  low-FODMAP  foods,  only  to 
8
discover that prepared and packaged foods almost never provided this information.  
9
36.  Because this information was not provided on food labels, it was extremely 
10
difficult for Michelle to find food products that were certain to be low-FODMAP.  
11
37.  This meant that Michelle would typically spend several hours each time she went 
12
13 to the grocery store scouring food label ingredient lists in the desperate hope of identifying high-
14
FODMAP foods, so she could avoid them.  
15
38.  But even careful review of an ingredient list typically will not reveal whether a 
16
food is high or low in FODMAPs. 
17
39.  This is because different parts of the same type of ingredient can be high-
18
19 FODMAP or low-FODMAP.  
20
40.  For example, one part of a green onion will be low-FODMAP, while the rest of 
21
the green onion is high-FODMAP, so an ingredient list that includes โgreen onionsโ will be of no 
22
help to someone who is searching for low-FODMAP foods. 
23
41.  When a food productโs ingredient list features an ingredient that could potentially 
24
25 be low-FODMAP, that food product might nonetheless still be high-FODMAP. 
26
42.  Conversely, when a food productโs ingredient list features an ingredient that could 
27
potentially be high-FODMAP, that food product might nevertheless still be low-FODMAP. 
28
7 

Case 2:23-cv-00455-ART-DJA   Document 1   Filed 03/28/23   Page 8 of 32
 
1 43.  This made it extremely difficult for Michelle to find packaged foods indicating 
2
whether the foods were low-FODMAP.  
3
44.  In the first few months in which Michelle attempted to stop eating high-FODMAP 
4
foods,  she  barely  ate  because  she  could  not  find  enough  low-FODMAP  foods,  and  she 
5
consequently suffered an unhealthy amount of significant weight loss. 
6
7 45.  Eventually, Michelle was able to piece together a low-FODMAP diet for herself, 
8
but the lack of low-FODMAP labeling continues to negatively impact her quality of life.  
9
46.  Michelle desperately needs to know which prepared and packaged foods are low-
10
FODMAP.  
11
47.  Michelleโs quality of life would be substantially improved if food labels were 
12
13 allowed to indicate whether the foods were low-FODMAP.  
14
48.  Upon information and belief, and given the prevalence of IBS and other digestive 
15
disorders in the United States, many food businesses would make more low-FODMAP foods if 
16
they were allowed to tell consumers on their food labels that the low-FODMAP foods were indeed 
17
low-FODMAP. 
18
19 49.  Michelle knows of at least one food producer that would provide this truthful, 
20
factual low-FODMAP information on its food labels if the Ban were not prohibiting the food 
21
producer from communicating that information.  
22
B.  Plaintiffs Ketan Vakil and Gourmend want customers to know that their foods 
23
are low-FODMAP. 
 
24
50.  Ketan Vakil is an entrepreneur who lives in New York, New York. Ketan has a 
25
master's degree in business administration from New York University.  
26
51.  Like Michelle, Ketan suffers from a digestive disorder.  
27
28
8 

Case 2:23-cv-00455-ART-DJA   Document 1   Filed 03/28/23   Page 9 of 32
 
1 52.  Like  Michelle,  Ketan  has  decided  to  follow  a  low-FODMAP  diet  to  avoid 
2
digestive pain. 
3
53.  Like Michelle, when Ketan tried to find packaged foods with labels indicating that 
4
they are low-FODMAP, he found it to be nearly impossible and highly frustrating. 
5
54.  Ketan loves good food. He developed a few recipes for low-FODMAP broths and 
6
7 spice blends that helped impart great flavor into his low-FODMAP diet so he could continue to 
8
enjoy eating. 
9
55.  Eventually, it occurred to Ketan that others like him with sensitive stomachs might 
10
appreciate his low-FODMAP recipes.   
11
56.  Ketan sawโand experienced for himselfโan unmet need in the marketplace: 
12
13 foods that could be trusted to be low-FODMAP.  
14
57.  Not realizing that the lack of options in the marketplace had been caused by the 
15
federal  governmentโs  Ban,  Ketan  decided  to  start  a  business  dedicated  to  producing  low-
16
FODMAP foods.  
17
58.  In 2018, Ketan founded Gourmend to do just that. 
18
19 59.  Gourmend is a food business that develops, markets, and sells food products that 
20
are low-FODMAP. 
21
60.  Ketan is the sole employee of Gourmend. 
22
61.  Gourmend  works  with  co-manufacturers  and  co-packers  to  manufacture  and 
23
package Gourmendโs products to Gourmendโs specifications. 
24
25 62.  Gourmend currently sells its food products to consumers throughout the United 
26
States. 
27
28
9

21 U.S.C. ยงยง 601 et seq. (the Federal Meat Inspection Act (โFMIAโ)). Specifically, ยง 607 of the

has been delegated the primary responsibility of regulating meat products under the FMIA, 
21
22 including the regulation of labels. 7 C.F.R. ยง 2.18(a)(1)(ii)(B) and ยง 2.53(a)(2)(ii).

to 21 U.S.C. ยงยง 301 et seq. (the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (โFFDCAโ)) and 15 U.S.C.

1 86.  21 U.S.C ยง 607(d) provides that โno article subject to [the FMIA] shall be sold . . . 
2
under any name or other marking or labeling which is false or misleading . . . but established trade 
3
names and other marking and labeling and containers which are not false or misleading and which 
4
are approved by the Secretary are permitted.โ 
5
87.  21 U.S.C ยง 607(e) provides that โ[i]f the Secretary has reason to believe that any 
6
7 marking or labeling . . . in use or proposed for use with respect to any article subject to [the FMIA 
8
/ the PPIA] is false or misleading in any particular, he may direct that such use be withheld unless 
9
the marking, labeling, or container is modified in such manner as he may prescribe so that it will 
10
not be false or misleading.โ 
11
88.  21 U.S.C ยง 601(n)(1) and 21 U.S.C. ยง 343(a) provide that a food is โmisbranded,โ 
12
13 and therefore violates the FMIA or FFDCA, if the foodโs label โis false or misleading in any 
14
particular.โ 
15
89.  21 U.S.C. ยง 343(a) states, similar to the FMIA, that a food product is misbranded 
16
if โits labeling is false or misleading in any particular[.]โ 
17
90.  The FMIA and FFCDA both define โlabel,โ in relevant part, as โa display of 
18
19 written, printed, or graphic matter upon the immediate container (not including package liners) 
20
of any article.โ 21 U.S.C. ยง 601(o) and ยง 321(k). 
21
91.  The FMIA and FFCDA both define โlabelingโ as โall labels and other written, 
22
printed, or graphic matter (1) upon any article or any of its containers or wrappers, or (2) 
23
accompanying such article.โ 21 U.S.C. ยง 601(p) and 21 U.S.C. ยง 321(m). 
24
25 92.  This definition of โlabelingโ is broad, making the regulations applicable not only 
26
to product labels, but also to materials that accompany the product. For instance, the definition 
27
can encompass point-of purchase materials.

labeling standards to avoid inconsistency. 21 U.S.C. ยง 607(c); 15 U.S.C. ยง 1455(c). As a result, 
3
the USDAโs and the FDAโs food labeling regulations largely mirror each other, and regulators at 
4

7 nutrient content claims are allowed.

95.  The result is that โimpliedโ or โundefinedโ nutrient content claims are not allowed

96.  For the purposes of determining whether a nutrient content claim is Banned for

being โimpliedโ or โundefined,โ โdefinedโ means defined in the federal regulations.

103.  Even though USDA and FDA food labeling standards and regulations mirror each 
4
other, the USDA and the FDA enforce those standards and regulations differently.  
5
104.  The relevant USDA enabling statute, the FMIA, provides that โestablished trade 
6
7 names and other marking and labeling and containers which are not false or misleading and which 
8
are approved by the Secretary are permitted.โ 21 U.S.C ยง 607(d). 
9
105.  The USDA interprets these provisions as mandating that USDA must preapprove 
10
food labels before those foods can be offered for sale. Therefore, before a food seller is legally 
11
permitted to offer a food product for sale, it must get its label pre-approved by the USDA (through 
12
13 FSIS).  
14
106.  The relevant FDA enabling statutes do not have a similar provision. They simply 
15
provide  that  misbranded  labels  are  prohibited  and  that  the  Secretary  has  the  authority  to 
16
promulgate regulations โfor the efficient enforcement of [the statute].โ 21 U.S.C. 331(a); 21 
17
U.S.C. 371(a).  
18
19 107.  The FDA has not adopted the USDAโs label pre-approval requirement. Instead, 
20
the FDA monitors compliance through surveillance of products already on the market and 
21
enforces its regulations by sending โwarning lettersโ to food manufacturers.  
22
108.  21 U.S.C ยง 610(c) (FMIA) and 21 U.S.C. ยง 331 (FFDCA) prohibit the introduction 
23
of misbranded food into interstate commerce.  
24
25 109.  Pursuant to 21 U.S.C. ยง 676(a) and 21 U.S.C. ยง 333(a), each violation can result 
26
in imprisonment of up to one year, a fine of up to $1,000, or both. 
27
